title: Cant switch themes after updating to 5.0
author: Jonesie

comments.body:
It is actually slightly easier to do in the 5.0 release.

You still need to get an instance of the `Theme`. This will typically be done with `PaletteHelper.GetTheme()` or the `GetTheme()` extension method on `ResourceDictionary`. Once you have that theme instance you can switch between Light/Dark themes simply by calling `SetDarkTheme()`/`SetLightTheme()` directly on it, which will update the internal brushes with the corresponding values. Finally, to apply the theme, you will need to call `PaletteHelper.SetTheme(Theme)` or more generically the `SetTheme()` extension method on `ResourceDictionary`.

        </Style>

title: Please don't unnecessarily mark classes as internal (particularly classes used in the XAML templates/styles)
body:
As I'm working on upgrading to v4.0.0 from v3.1.3, part of my process involves copying/pasting the templates of the controls that I've highly customized for my projects in order to gain complete control over the full look-and-feel.

Unfortunately, some of the classes in this library are marked `internal` (seemingly for no reason, but I could be missing some key aspect of this), and so I have to then copy the source of that class as well and point it to my copy.

Example (at the top of `MaterialDesignTheme.TextBox.xaml`):
```xml
    <converters:TextFieldClearButtonVisibilityConverter x:Key="ClearButtonVisibilityConverter" />
```
where `TextFieldClearButtonVisibilityConverter` is `internal` and so I have to copy/paste the source when customizing this file.

If all converters (and other supporting utilities referenced by the templates/styles) could be marked as public, this would save a good bit of time during upgrades.
author: SirUppyPancakes

comments.body:
Part of the reason for marking classes as internal rather than public is to keep the public API simpler. Many of those converters don't do much (or any error checking of their parameters), lack documentation, and highly specific to a given templates implements. This makes them less than ideal to be part of the library's public API. 
Often the contents of a control's template is treated as an implementation detail therefore not considered public. This is why many of the converters that are intended to simply support that template are marked as internal. I am not opposed to making more of the converters public, though ones like `TextFieldClearButtonVisibilityConverter` would need to be updated to handle error cases; and ideally unit tests.

You definitely make some fair points, and it seems that the existing XAML practices around producing and consuming libraries may just be at odds with those around clean APIs and composable code. It isn't an ideal situation, but I can respect the choice to leave some things internal in favor of retaining a cleaner public API.

XAML does offer quite a lot of benefits, so I suppose I'll just have to accept its flaws when it comes to stuff like this; and it helps that I only really have to hack around with it during big upgrades. Thanks for taking the time to reply and explain the choice! Feel free to close this as you see fit.

I do appreciate the feedback. I was not aware many people were copying the styles into their own projects so I will try to be conscious of that workflow going forward to avoid making things difficult.

body:
Hi, this is more of a question then issue.

Are you going to add Keys to all the styles and templates?

It's really irritating that i have to create styles for every control and everything because your templates and styles override the default looks and behaviours.  I mean, I love your controls and all of it, but sometimes i have some of my styles, some of them just slightly alter the default versions of items, and somewhere i really just use the default items. But now i have to rewrite styles of each control due to overlapping.

Is it possible to evade that somehow  ? 

P.S. where can i see a roadmap or something like that? When do we expect 4.0.0?
author: phantomfuxor

comments.body:
I think that you could try to not import 
`<ResourceDictionary Source="pack://application:,,,/MaterialDesignThemes.Wpf;component/Themes/MaterialDesignTheme.Defaults.xaml" />`
in your `app.xaml`. It's this file that override most of the default styles.
Then you could pick individually each style that you like, or create your own version of `MaterialDesignTheme.Defaults.xaml`.

Yes, but. If you want to override a style you have to add the default style to the app.xaml to have its BasedOn overridden, and then adding your own res. dict. to override that in app xaml.  

I thought it was possible to extract style from a namespace for BasedOn usage since i only want to override maybe a few controls.

@phantomfuxor most of the controls have styles in their own resource dictionaries. Those resource dictionaries should not have any implicit styles so you should be able to reference the ones that you want without getting any implicit styles. 

The other thing to note is that technically all of the styles do have keys set on them. The implicit styles (the ones with just a TargetType, and no explicit x:Key), can be reference in your BasedOn by using the type. For example if you want to extend the default button style you can do something like this:

```XAML
<Style TargetType="Button" BasedOn="{StaticResource {x:Type Button}}">
...
</Style>
```

title: How to set TextAlignment of the materialDesign:HintAssist.Hint

I have TextBox with the `MaterialDesignOutlinedTextFieldTextBox` styles. Now I want to align text in the center of TextBox, But I can't find any option in `materialDesign:HintAssist` to align hint text.

author: bezzad

comments.body:
Currently not supported. But you can override the property like this.
```xml
            <TextBox Style="{StaticResource MaterialDesignOutlinedTextFieldTextBox}"
                     TextAlignment="Center"
                     materialDesign:HintAssist.Hint="Hint Text">
                <TextBox.Resources>
                    <Style TargetType="{x:Type materialDesign:SmartHint}">
                        <Setter Property="HorizontalAlignment" Value="Center"/>
                    </Style>
                </TextBox.Resources>
            </TextBox>
```

title: It's not possible to base own styles on all materialDesign Styles, because not all have keys
body:
Example: default style of ColorZone
If you load the package from NuGet you dont have access to the default colorZone Style, so if you want to change something you have to copy the whole style and can not just base your style on the default one.

One possible solution would be, to add keys to all styles and add new styles without keys, that are based on the old styles but change nothing.
So the controls would still have default styles, but the user could also write own styles that are based on the default styles.
author: speedyalibaba

comments.body:
There is only one style for the `ColorZone` control so you can just base your custom style on the default style like this:

```
<Style x:Key="MyColorZone" TargetType="materialDesign:ColorZone">
   <Setter Property="Mode" Value="Inverted"/>
   <Setter Property="Padding" Value="16"/>
</Style>
```

title: Set color of input to use PrimaryLight instead of PrimaryMid when selected?
body: I'm trying to use text inputs on the dark theme background but the primary mid hue of the default color scheme is too dark. Is there a way to set the input to use the light variant of the color scheme when it's focused? Looking at the source it appears to be hardcoded.
author: JamesCoyle

comments.body:
@JamesCoyle all of the brushes should be using DyanmicResources. So all you need to do is declare a resource with a matching key at the text box level and it will get used. In this case I suspect the resource you want to override is the `PrimaryHueMidBrush`. So something like this:
```XAML
<TextBox>
    <TextBox.Resources>
        <SolidColorBrush x:Key="PrimaryHueMidBrush" Color="{DynamicResource Primary200}" />
    </TextBox.Resources>
</TextBox>
```
Depending on which color theme you are using you may need to adjust which color resource you use, but most of them use Primary200 and the color for the `PrimaryHueLightBrush`
Ah of course! Thanks for the help!

title: Improve DialogHost.Show behavior
body:
I'm currently using the `DialogHost.Show()` method in my ViewModels.
Aside from using a static call in my ViewModels isn't that good, the current behavior could improve in my opinion.

It's ugly to wrap every `.Show()` within a try catch block, because I can't check if the DialogHost is open.
I could think of these possibilities:

- Add a queue like the Snackbar has it
- Force close the previous dialog (by overload)
- Ignore the next to be shown dialog if one is currently open (by overload)
- Add a static CheckOpen method with optional dialog identifier as overload
author: uPloraX

comments.body:
Though there is certainly room to improve the DialogHost API, I would suggestion using dependency injection to solve this particular problem. 
Rather than litter my view models with static calls to `DialogHost.Show()`, I instead have an `IDialogService` that is passed to the view models. Because all of the dialog interaction flows through this class it can easily track things like which dialog hosts are open.
